Comments: Fruits, seeds, leaves, flowers, small aquatic animals and termites. In the study at Kilum, 52% of the diet was fruit and seeds
Diets may consist of up to 70% leaves, with fruits, flowers and other plant parts making up the remainder.
54% young leaves, 21.5% mature leaves, typically juicy pulp, yellow, red and orange drups and berries; and 12.6% flowers

Composed of fruits, nectar, flowers, leaves, fungi and insects. Azara's night monkeys there were more folivorous than the black headed night monkeys in Peru, concentrating on leaves of small trees and vines for 46% of their feeding time and with fruit being only 16% of the diet (as opposed to 60%) and nectar and flowers 33%.

Region: Centro Poblado La Esperanza, Amazonas Department

Comments: The study did not consider animal prey
Buds, sprouting buds and young leaves
Mainly inmature leaves and buds, supplemented ith fruits, flowers and bark.
Although very little is known diets includes fruits, smll animal prey (especially insects), and of particular significnce exudates

Highly frugivorous 43-74% of teh diet) but they also eat relatively large quantities of leaves 85-33%, and flowers 11-24%. Arthropods are a minor proportion of their diets 0-4% in all but one case 10%.
Eats mainly insects and small vertebrates.

The diet of C. albifrons includes fruits, small invertebrates, their eggs and larvae, small mammals, lizards, and bird’s eggs. They especially like to eat ant and wasp larvae, and are adept at robbing beehives for honey.
Mainly ripe fruits and insects, but also leaves, flowrs and bird eggs.
Fruit and insects are the principal components. Fruit comprises 99% of the plant part ot the diet in the wet season and 53% in the dry season.
Includes fruits, insects, snails, crabs, clams, slugs, frogs, lizards, nestling and Coati pups, and tree rats. They also eat eggs

Includes fruits, flowers, seeds, insects and other arthropods, bird eggs and small vertebrates. In a study at Tiputini a group spent c- 10% of their day feeding on fruits and 54% foraging for animal prey.

All tarsiers are 100% carnivorous and eat only live-caught animal prey. There are no data that allow for direct comparisons of diet among species; thus is not known if reported differences in diet are due to availability, sampling or actual differences. Is reported to eat mainly insects, including beetles, grasshoppers, cockroaches moths butterflies...
Presumed to be mainly fruits, such as figs, sugar plums, dika nuts, raphia and dwarf datepalms
Mainly fruits, along with seeds, other plant material and some animal prey
Fruit is the main constituent of the diets and they also eat leaves, flowers, insects, and other small mamals.
Mainly on fruits, supplemented with young leaves and shoots from plants.
Eats leaf petioles, ripe and unripe fruits, flower buds, and meristems of two species of terrestrial herbaceous Marantaceae.
Mainly fruit and they also eat leaves, seeds, flowers, bark and insects. In one area, arthropod dominated the diet, 56-63% with cultivated fruits making up 24-26%.
Proportion of diet is related to an analysis of food acquired in trees only
No doubt mainly fruits, along with leaves and animal prey. In villages they are considered sacred,  they eat agricultural crops and steal food from houses.

Mainly on fruits and flowers, young vine leaves and buds, with insect prey constituting only a minor part of its diet. Flower nectar seems to be a particularly important food item just after individuals emerge from estivation.
Fruits, flowers, seeds and the tender part of plants are dietary staples, with invertebrates being eaten in small amounts and semall vertebrates taken on ocasión
59.4% fruits, 26.9% immature seeds, 6.4% leaves, 3.9% flowers, and 3.4% insects and spiders.
They did not consider animal prey
Feeds on fruit, seeds, flowers, gum and bird eggs. Invertebrates and some small vertebrates are also included the diet but detailed dietary data are not available
Mainly young leaves, mature leaves and unripe seeds, supplemented with shoots, fruits (mainly unripe), flowers and termite clay
Consists principally of fruits, flowers, nectar, seeds and leaves. Also invertebrates

All feeding bouts (>15 sec) initiated by the focal animal were recorded during an all-day follow. The duration of each feeding bout and
the type of food consumed were recorded. Feeding bout duration was determined by recording the time (hour, minute, and seconds) the focal
animal began feeding (placing food in the mouth) and stopped feeding in
a food source. A bout was considered to have ended if the focal animal
paused from feeding for >15 sec. The times spent feeding and foraging
were combined into total feeding time because the focal animal often was
obscured by foliage or scanning the tree for the next fruit while he or she
ate. The total number of feeding bouts per day and the total amount of
time the focal animal devoted to feeding each day also could be derived
from these data because feeding data were collected on an all-occurrence
basis.

Highly frugivorous for a colobine, although the proportion of the diet that is fruit and seeds appears to vary with habitat. In one study in a prpimary forest habitat, fruit made up only 32% of the diet, while in a second study in secondary forest fruit and seeds contributed 70% of the diet. Leaves can still make up a significant portion of the dit 22-55%. They also eats flowers, sap, bark, and fungi and it si one of the few primates that can eat leaves of the dipterocarp tree family
Has not been studied but it is probably highly frugivorous for a colobine, but also highly folivorous.

Fruits, flowers, leaves of bromeliads, palm hearts and small animal prey, including insects, birds (and bird eggs), lizards and small mammals. They feed also on cultivated exotic species such as oil palm, jackfuit, and cacao.

Frugivore, eating mainly fuirts and gums, supplemented with young leaves and certain types of wood. Some invertebrates and frogs are aso eaten. It is frequently seen in banana trees where it selects the ripest fruits.
Presumably similar in its diet and feeding habits to the other Himalayan species (S. schitaceus o S. hector)
